title: CSRC Said to Greet Latest Stock Market Crash with Calm
text:
CSRC Said to Greet Latest Stock Market Crash with Calm No one worked overtime awaiting orders from higher-ups this time, person close to regulator says By staff reporter Mo Su and Washington correspondent Zhang Yuan'an 
(Beijing) â€“ The securities regulator apparently reacted with calm to the worst crash the A-share market has suffered in more than eight years on August 24, in contrast to the robust intervention seen the month before. 
"Even though the Shanghai Composite Index fell by almost 9 percent, no one was required to put in extra hours after work," a person close to the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) said on August 24. "In the past whenever the market fell too sharply, bureaus related to monitoring trading data from stock exchanges had to work overtime and stand by for orders from higher-ups." 
The regulator did not ask for special reports on trading activities as it usually does after sharp fluctuations, the source said. 
The reaction was surprisingly muted given that the Shanghai index fell by 8.49 percent by the time trading closed, the largest single-day decline since March 2007. 
A similar fall on July 27 sent the CSRC scrambling to calm investors. It called a late-night press conference to announce that state-backed investors would continue to buy stocks to stabilize the market. 
Its indifference this time showed that the regulator had a new attitude about intervening in the stock market, another person close to the CSRC said. Officials "no longer feel the imperative to comb through data for clues to what triggered the fall," that person said. 
The source said he believed the CSRC has decided to be more cautious about intervention and do it less. 
The fall of the A-share index preceded what turned out to the most turbulent day that many major stock exchanges around the world have seen in years. Many media reports linked this volatility to the Chinese bourse's performance, saying its crash exacerbated investor concerns about the country's economy. 
Analysts cited two other factors as contributing to problems in China. The first was a weakening yuan and the other was slower manufacturing activity, as reflected by the early Caixin China Purchasing Managers' Index , which hit a 77-month low at 47.1 points in August. 
However, Jacob Kirkegaard, a senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics, a think tank in Washington, said neither a global nor a regional crisis is on the horizon, as some analysts have suggested. 
The fall in the A-share market was predictable considering how fast it soared over the past year, he said, though he said it is hard to predict whether the correction will continue because it is unclear how much of the growth over the past year was driven by speculative investment and how much was due to improvements in business and economic conditions. 
European stock markets overacted to signs of the Chinese economy slowing and would recover after the U.S. stock market stabilizes, Kirkegaard said.
